abstract: On Sunday, an International Monetary Fund official gave a grim prognosis for the world’s advanced economies.
snippet: On Sunday, an International Monetary Fund official gave a grim prognosis for the world’s advanced economies.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The global economic crisis has left “deep scars” in the fiscal balances of the world’s advanced economies, which should begin to rein in spending next year as the recovery continues, the No. 2 official at the International Monetary Fund said on Sunday in Beijing.

headline.main: I.M.F. Gives Debt Warning for the Wealthiest Nations
headline.print_headline: I.M.F. Gives Debt Warning For the Wealthiest Nations

byline.original: By Keith Bradsher and Sewell Chan

abstract: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.
snippet: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the s...
lead_paragraph: The Bank of America chief executive Brian Moynihan is making his first trip to China this week as the lender pushes to catch up with rivals in the world’s fastest-growing economy, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline.main: Moynihan Said to Plan First Trip to China

abstract: The China Poly Real Estate Group, one of the country’s biggest property developers, plans to raise up to $1.4 billion through a private placement of shares to fund expansion.
snippet: The China Poly Real Estate Group, one of the country’s biggest property developers, plans to raise up to $1.4 billion through a private placement of shares to fund expansion.
lead_paragraph: The China Poly Real Estate Group, one of the country’s biggest property developers, planned to raise up to 9.6 billion yuan ($1.4 billion) through a private placement of shares to fund expansion, Reuters reported.

headline.main: China Poly Seeks $1.4 Billion in Placement

abstract: Three employees of Rio Tinto, the British-Australian mining giant, agreed to plead guilty Monday to taking bribes while working for the company in China, stunning confessions on the opening day of their three-day trial here.
snippet: Three employees of Rio Tinto, the British-Australian mining giant, agreed to plead guilty Monday to taking bribes while working for the company in China, stunning confessions on the opening day of their three-day trial here.
lead_paragraph: Three employees of Rio Tinto, the British-Australian mining giant, agreed to plead guilty Monday to taking bribes while working for the company in China, stunning confessions on the opening day of their three-day trial here.

headline.main: China Begins Trial of 4 Rio Tinto Employees

abstract: As it looks to increase its presence in China, UBS could set up a renminbi-focused private equity fund and is holding discussions with Beijing’s municipal government on the matter, The Financial Times reported.
snippet: As it looks to increase its presence in China, UBS could set up a renminbi-focused private equity fund and is holding discussions with Beijing’s municipal government on the matter, The Financial Times reported.
lead_paragraph: As it looks to increase its presence in China, UBS could set up a renminbi-focused private equity fund and is holding discussions with Beijing’s municipal government on the matter, The Financial Times reported.

headline.main: UBS May Set Up New Renminbi Fund

abstract: Google said it would direct users to an uncensored version based in Hong Kong. China on Tuesday said the case would not affect ties with the U.S. “unless politicized” by others.
snippet: Google said it would direct users to an uncensored version based in Hong Kong. China on Tuesday said the case would not affect ties with the U.S. “unless politicized” by others.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Just over two months after threatening to leave China because of censorship and intrusions from hackers, Google on Monday closed its Internet search service there and began directing users in that country to its uncensored search engine in Hong Kong.

headline.main: Google Shuts China Site in Dispute Over Censorship
headline.print_headline: Google Closes Search Service Based In China

byline.original: By Miguel Helft and David Barboza
